text: 12 oz bottle at home from notes. Pours a clear auburn brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted caramel, toffee, light nutty character, lager yeast, decent.

Bottle from Wegmans. Pours hazy brown, tan head. Coffee in the nose, pumpernickel bread, coffee. I hate to be negative, but at what point does Garrett Oliver become rich enough to hand this establishment over to someone who can actually brew good beer?

Delicious dunkel. Wish there were more of these out there. Aroma was good. Dark roasted malt with that distinct lager smell. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a thin off white film for a head. Taste was nice. Bitter roasted malt and slight notes of coffee.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle @ Jungle Jims / Cincinnati OH --- BB Mar 2017 --- Aroma of roasted malt. Nearly opaque brown-black color, creamy beige head that stays, strings of lace. Taste is somewhat chalky lightly roasted malt with a overtone of wet cardboard. No bittering necessary, as the malt itself has bitter already. This may be enough past its prime that Im not getting the true brew.

Bottle, first night of the  move in  , pours a dark brown pour with an ephemeral beige head. Nose is rich caramel and malt. Taste is rather sweet malt and caramel , syrupy and thick with cocoa nibs. Finishes on the same tasting notes with descent lacing and a moderately large my finish . Quaff Score 7 / 10

Pours a dark brown, almost black with some ruby red shining through when held up to the glass. There is a small one-finger tan head that does leave some nice lacing around the glass. The aroma is dark brown bread, roasted barley malts, and some sweetness. The flavor is similar to the aroma. There is not much hop presence but the barley has a much darker burnt note in the flavor than it does in the aroma. The mouthfeel is medium and drinkability is also medium.

I know weve not posted in a while, fixing that right now. With that said, Ive always been intrigued by deceptive beers. Theres a certain wow factor when your eyes tell you a beer should taste and smell a certain way due to its appearance, but completely blind-sides you with the exact opposite. Golden Stouts are the new craze on that, but the original Decepticons, if you will, are Dark Lagers and.... Full review here https://agrainoftruthblog.wordpress.com

12oz bottle - the pour is a dark brownish red - almost black & cola like with a thin off white head. Light roasty aroma with notes of nuttiness, toast and a hint of piney hops. Decent flavors dominated by mild roasted barley, nut brown, americano coffee, earth and a very short aftertaste.
Have tried once or twice. Not a huge fan. Probably the best option on the menu, or picked because I was feeling adventurous at the time of ordering.

On tap at Singer Tavern Finsbury Square. Black beer very dark brown. Lasting tan head. Some dark malt. Over carbonated. Dwrk syrup on the aroma. Some treacle molasses in mouth. Ok. Could take or leave this one.

Not sure why this isnt categorized as a Schwarzbier. Dark brown or black lager, malty with some roast underneath. Hops are mostly to dry it out (and it is dry, not sweet). Fairly high carbonation level. Well, it is a lager. Maybe not as rich as Id have liked, but again, its a lager, not a porter or stout. More of a "well done" than a "bravo!"

Appearance is dark brown almost black. Almost no light penetration. Aroma is heavy malt and hints of chocolate. Taste follows nose but isn't harsh. Toasted malts come through beautifully. Mouthfeel is light, not at all thick. Very tasty.

*12 oz bottle into pint glass
Bottle - pours dark brown tan head - nose/taste of light chocolate, coffee and lager yeast - medium body

Not sure where Dunkel/Tmavy ends and Schwarzbier begins, but what the hell. Regardless, Insulated drinks well, mixing a heavy roasted coffee maltiness with the easygoing fresh-fruit tang of a traditional Lager. Estery as all hell yet manageable thanks to the dark malt bitterness, and the dry finish eases any Euro-malt sweet corn doldrums. Surprisingly tasty.

Draft to taster at The Pint Room. Looks solid; a slightly cloudy iced tea color with eggshell head. Smells malty with notes of piney hops, lager yeast, and a touch of coffee. Tastes like it smells, but less hoppy, and with a bit of toast in its place. Mouthfeel is medium-light to medium-bodied. Inoffensive, but underwhelming and unmemorable.
Faint coca aroma with a roasty chocolate malts with a bit of maple syrup in the body.

Bottle, Wine Warehouse. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is citrus, dark fruit, floral hops, light coffee, light chocolate. Flavor is bittersweet nuttiness, dark fruit, coffee, chocolates, earth. Tasty!

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted/woody malt, caramel, chocolate, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, hops, dark chocolate, and nuts; Finish is dry & slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Well done - very enjoyable.

12oz bottle poured into willibecker glass. Brown, big creamy head. Light lacing as I drink it. Sweet malts aroma - caramel, woodsy earth, soil, bark, sweet but still nicely lagered. Flavor has a tingly carbonation that offsets and makes it feel lighter. A lighter bitter finish. Woodsy, lightly sweet again. Short finish. Flavorful and light. Could use some more lagering to crisp it up and clean it out. But decent lagers are hard to come by.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: malty, faint roasty aromas. black in color with nice faint brown head. taste is primarily of coffee and roasted barley, faint hints of chocolate. finishes smooth and clean.

Bottle from Fountainhall Wines. Aromas of treacle toffee with feint chocolate and coffee beans. It has a super dark ruby appearance with a foamy light tan head. The tastes are strong roast malt with a bittering deep treacle that blends beautifully and doesnt feel as "sickly" sweet as some dark ales. It has a surprising sparkle which produces a lighter body than the appearance would suggest. This is a lovely winter seasonal beer.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle with a Best By March 2017 date on the bottle. Attractive and on-target looking dark brown pour with a lingering tan colored head. The aroma is toasted dark malts and bread crust note. Some sweetness. Low hop profile. The body is around medium. The taste has the same dark toasted malt and crust character. A burnt character too.
Tap at Ho-Ho-Kus Inn & Tavern. Pours black, tan white head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, little smokey. Flavor is super roasted malt, chocolate, minimal bitterness. Very roasted.

On tap. It poured a dark brown color with an off-white head. The aroma was of toasted malts, bread and some hops. The taste was similar to the aroma with more toasted malts, breadiness, hops and a touch of coffee. It had a medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. This was really good.

30-NOV-2016, draft @Carmines NY.
Dark brown with a lasting tan head. Very nice aroma of roast - coffee. Taste is nice roast as well. Not burnt, just pleasant roast, bread and perhaps coffee. Medium body. Really a pleasant surprise:-)

Bardzo dobry dunkel. Piana trwala brazowo fioletowa, kremowa, znaczaca na szkle swoja koronke. Niesamowicie ciemne piwo, nieprzezroczysta barwa bardzo ciemnego brazu. Zapach palonego drzewa. W smaku takze dosc spora palonosc, goryczka srtednia ale ciagle obecna przy kazdym lyku. Zblizone do Stouta, choc to nie ta fernmentacja.

After having so many Brooklyn beers that fall far short of their lofting rating, its nice to finally wholeheartedly agree with one. A nice spiced aroma, this has a good complex flavor. Great winter beer and it works even now in the summer Vegas heat.
Bottle. Black with a small head. Gentle smoked flavour with some bitterness. A medium body rounds off a pleasant beer.

Keg at BD Clerko, 07/07/16.
Mahogany brown with a decent light tan head.
Nose is earthy dark fruits, faint cocoa powder, light spice.
Taste comprises brown bread, toasted malt, toffee, cocoa powder, biscuit, dark fruit rinds.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid for style.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Tap. Black with cocoa bubbly head. Sweet, some grape, sugar. Very light considering the style - nice and drinkable. Dry finish. Quite solid.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Leicester. Black beer with a strong light brown coloured head. The aroma is lightly roasted and yeasty, and the flavour is mildly roasted with a touch of maltyness and lightly coffee roastedness. Overall a nice dark beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
355ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a deep dark brown with a small tan head. Toffee and biscuit aroma, quite roasty. Similar flavor, very smooth, great mouthfeel.
Keg at brew dog dark brown.. Thin tan lacing.. Soft sweet biscuits toffee malts nose.. Soft toffee malts dry fruit

Superb appearance with a rich dark brown color and a pillowy tan head that just wont quit. The aromas are subtle and multi-faceted, featuring lots of roastiness, coffee, and chocolate cake or chocolate donut. On the body, no nonsense at all. Clean, lager-like finish, making it not quite as interesting as a great porter, for example, but it is true to its style. The roastiness notes will linger on the palate for over a minute. A very well-brewed beer indeed!
Keg at Brewdog Edinburgh. Pours dark brown, beige head. Nose is chocolate, gentle roast, sweetish dark malts. Tastes similar. This is way better than I expected.
Keg, Brewdog Leicester. Dark brown with a beige head. Earthy with berries and chocolate. Coffee with plummy fruit. Lightly woody. Alcohol is non-existent. Good.

Taste: spiced, bready grains, toasted dark malts and peat, with some hop character.
complex toasted malt and hint of coffee bean nose. Dark brown and clear, with a soft tan foamy head, with some lace to glass. Medium/full body. A fine finish a tangy version of some scotch ales of lately.

Nose with damp leaves/straw, malty (cocoa power dusting); very slight fire ash smell. Mildly bitter, fizzier than Brooklyn Winter Ale (tried alongside; not a v different taste profile at all, but v different mouthfeel). Finishes on coffee grounds, and the slight (short) creaminess of cheddar cheese on cracker. "Hey, Spanish negra beers: jus takealook at dis baby from Brooklyn!"

Dark brown pour and tan lace. Smelling like nut, caramel, chili powder and roasted malts. Flavor is burnt, molasses, coffee, malt, hop and a tiny bit of fruit. Kinda 1-D but ya know, its good. This is becoming one of my favorite styles.
From bottle. Pours opaque black. Nose of toffee, roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate. Medium body, smokey, roasty-toasty.

From a 12 oz bottle into a Belgian snifter after 15 minutes of warming.

Pours dark brown with a modest off-white head that quickly subsides to a thin ring; light lacing. Essentially black and opaque in the glass. 

Nose: bread, subtle coffee, cocoa, and faint spicy hops. 

Flavor: lightly sweet up front with a mildly bitter finish. Medium and dark roasted grains dominate but theres more than a touch of hoppy spiciness. Coffee and cocoa notes. 
. 
Mouthfeel: smooth, medium-light body and near medium carbonation, semi-dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a black color with off white head. Roasty, malty, soapy aromas. Roasty, soapy, sweet malty, slight ashy flavors. I was excited to try this, but just wasnt too impressed - kinda soapy and sweet and a little messy.

Pours a dark brown black with a thin off-white to tan colored head. The aroma is chocolates and some roast, chocolate, coffee, caramel. Flavor follows suit. Some ashy notes. Very dry and awesome finish.

Rated on 5-08-2016 at 800 Degrees Three Fires, Fort Wayne, IN. (Draft) The appearance when served is a small beige head that is fully lasting, golden transparent body, very little carbonation observed, and spotty lacing. The aroma is lightly floral, roasted, chocolate, caramel, and malt. The flavor is sweet, roasted, chocolate, caramel malt, and a dry finish. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is light-medium bodied. This is an easy drinking beer but overall nothing really stands out about this beer for me.

This draft brew from a restaurant poured a head of foamy white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a uncarbonated transparent golden orange colored body and a good lacing. The weak aroma was malt hop. The sharp crisp and clean mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a lingering hoppy aftertaste. The sharp flavor contained notes of bitter and hops. A decent one that I would consider buying again.
Bottle at Cotteridge Wines; dark opaque brown pour with a bubbly beige head, aroma has bready malts and some chocolate, taste has dark fruits, sweet caramel, bread dough, coffee, pretty nice.

Bottle from Bradleys, Cork [150416]
Black, frothy off white head, some lacing
Aroma of soft lemon, US sweet caramel malts, no roast
Taste of soft roast, hint of black tea, US caramel malts, slight citrus, bit odd tbh
Palate - Soft carb, medium body, soft sweet, mellow bitter. Finish - getting that black tea again, slight tannic, soft roast
Overall - Not sure what theyre trying to do here - not one of their best

Excellent dunkel-esque dark lager with requisite slightly roasted caramel malt, expressed with notes of chalky dry dark chocolate. However, the addition of earthy hops with cool bitterness akin to a Pilsner makes for a distinctive brew. Smooth medium-bodied palate on draft, with a crisp white head atop a rich mahogany-hued body. Overall another delicious fine-tuned beer from Brooklyn!
Keg @ Victorian Craft Beer Café, Halifax. Dark red with a thin off-white head. Has sweetened dark lager malty with mild roasted notes.

Bottle. Tawney, chocolate in glass. Thin head. Malt forward nose. Light ash. Taste follows. Thin body. Some chalk. Moves a bit towards bitter on finish. OK, but dont see myself picking up a sixer any time soon.
Fine dark roast flavor. Decent aroma of roast as well. Dark brown color. Light alternative to many stouts.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark brown body under a one inch tight bubbled beige head. The nose is rather delicious, nice roastiness and coffee notes with a light hoppiness. Very clean and tight. The flavor is pretty solid as well, very well lagered and clean. Nice roasted malt and coffee flavors with some light sweetness and licorice notes. A fairly prominent hop bitterness on the back end that keeps it from being too sweet. Medium bodied with a mouth coating cling and soft fizzy carbonation. Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a small head. Aromas of sweet malt, biscuit, caramel. Light bodied, nice beer,

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Table and Vine. Dark brown with lasting dense head and lace. Roasted caramel and nuts aroma. Burnt caramel nuts ash chocolate with very dry raosted coffee bitter finish. Medium light body fairly soft. Seems to lack any enticing malt quality. Its just burnt bitter and gone. Anyhow...I finished it so it gets a 3 or above.
Bottle. Pours black with a mid sized beige head, aroma is malty with some hints of fruit, taste is light bitterness with some malt with a dry finish.

Really hated this. Maybe just a bad batch? Doesnt seemed skunked or anything though. Seems much more woodsy/bitter that I would have guessed from the deScription. Thought this was trying to be a brown ipa. Not enjoyable.

Quick super market grab the other day which is nice way to disguise the tick expense in with groceries. Dark chocolate pour. Nose is roasted malt and caramel. Tastes of burnt sugar, caramel, roasted malt, light potting soil. Thin bodied. Easy drinking but nothing remarkable.

Aroma of some dark chocolate, and dark fruits, and a hint of smoke. Deep ebony color with a thick tan head. Sweet malt up front. Bitter chocolate, sweetness fades quickly to bitter chocolate. Watery mouth feel. Finish is malty chocolate with an increasing bitterness that lingers a bit after the sip. O.k.
Very dark brown pour. Aroma is light. The flavor is stronger than I expected. More hops. Not too sweet. Its good.
Pours cola brown with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt,coffee, and molasses. Strong coffee flavor with roasted malt bitterness and touch of molasses on the under side. Very nice.

Brooklyn Insulated Lager is a nice balance of malt and hops. Pours dark with a frothy head that lasts. Aroma is light and malty. Taste starts with roast malt flavors with a nice hoppy floral finish. Body is light and refreshing. Brooklyn Insulated Lager is the best of both worlds -- malt and hop!
Very dark brown with a cream colored head. Lacing is heavy. Aroma of toast, coffee, roast, and molasses. Taste is very roasty, and pretty bitter. Light-medium bodied and dry.

An interesting dark brew. This almost seems like a coffee porter with a light-medium body. There is some coffee and molasses in the flavor, plus a dash of herbs. Cheers to one of Brooklyns better releases.

Pours hardly translucent cola brown with a thick, fluffy tan head. Aroma, though not strong, tempts with roast malt and hints of caramel and woody hops. Flavor delivers woody hop, toasted malt and caramel notes. Firm body and so-so fizz lead to a caramel and toasty finish. Good insulation against a chilly winter day.

330ml bottle from Beer Merchants. Pours deep brown, off-white head. Aroma is grainy malt. Taste is good layered malts, light caramel sweetness, a touch of pine hop. Nice dunkel, although verges into Schwarzbier territory.

Nearly black appearance with a small tan head and good lacing. Subtle aroma of toasted malts mingling with tobacco. Bitter, herbal hops balanced the grainy, toasted malts in the taste, but did not overwhelm. A touch of sweetness lingered in the back of the aftertaste. Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel with an average length finish.

12 ounce bottle. Translucent dark brown pour. Moderate frothy khaki head. Earthy, sweet roasted malt nose. Flavors follows the nose, with additional notes of coffee and baked bread. Citrusy hops in middle and a hint of cola and dark fruit in finish.
Nose is coffee chocolate dark malt. Deep dark foggy cloudy bro. Taste is great coffee struck a lot chocolate with a bit of bitters. Full body with decent carbonation. Nice dunked lager.

Aroma: roasty, coffee, bread, earthy, 
Appearance: black with a beige head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish

Tasty
4 oz pour on draft at Spacebar. Dark brownish with light beige head. Aromas of grains, malt, wheat. Tastes of light chocolate, malt, caramel, light roast, spices. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

APPEARANCE- looks black when poured, but is really a very dark brown. Luxurious head clings to the glass beautifully, and sticks around until Im done with the full bottle. 
NOSE- very limited scent for me tonight. 
FLAVOR- slightly smoky with a strong malty backbone and finishes with just a touch of bitterness. 
NOTES-This has been the most refreshing beer that Ive had in the past several months.

12 oz bottle poured in a shaker. Nice rich malty aroma - hints of chocolate, coffee, fruit, and ginger. Flavor has notes of cinammon and clove along with a large dose of chocolate and roasted malt. Clean, slightly bitter, slightly burnt finish. Tastes almost like a very smooth chocolate stout with lagered crispness. Very good.

(Bottle). Pours a clear dark brown complexion with little to no head. Aroma of roasted malt. The flavor is a well roasted mild malt with faint hop balance. Not bad - mediocre. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Clear amber brown beer with a large beige head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, bread, herbs, hay, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is malty with notes of caramel, bread, herbs, coffee and molasses. Well balanced.
Keg at spitfire. Pours deep brown, nose is roasted, coffee, taste is sweet, chewy toffee, malty.

12oz bottle, from my local Whole Foods. BB Mar 2016. Clear dark red brown color. Ring of off-white head. Bits of lace. Medium body. Lighter to moderate carbonation, a bit fizzy. Mild bit of roughness. Moderate bitter taste, lighter sweet, nice dryness. Nice chocolate, dark fruit, toastiness, kinda spicy towards the end. More spicy as I went. Nice with my sandwich, but didnt hold up on its own. Too spicy and rough.
Bottle shared with Max and Podey. Pours a deep brown body with thin brown lacing. Medium bodied with notes of light round roast, soft bitter chocolate, pine resin and dirt. Decent.
Color of cola, flimsy beige head. Refreshing aroma, tea leaves, tobacco, sweet malts, brown sugar. Medium bodied, a dryish finish shrouded in well defined maltiness, some nutiness... Pretty good.
Just an average beer. Wouldnt go out of my way to drink. But better than basic beers

12oz bottle from Xroads. Poured a dense bodied pitch black with a smaller foamy beige head. Aroma of bad cola, nut shells, chocolate syrup, light smoke and cardboard. Flavor follows suit plus a touch of old raisins. Medium body with average carbonation and an average duration on the aftertaste.

Bottle. Dark brown with slight reddish tint, small foamy light beige head, faint coffee beans aroma, high carbonation, lightly bitter roasted malt taste, thin body, slight sweetness at the end, medium bitter finish. Well rounded and easy to drink.
Pours a dark brown from a bottle, basically smells and tastes like coffee cola. Meh.

Dark brown pour with a nice, medium sized, tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, light caramel, citrus and a little chocolate. Medium bodied, nice carbonation. Bitter, coffee, dark roast flavor up front. Citrus hops, primarily orange. Lingering, bitter finish. This one was a little too roasty and bitter for my tastes. I swear, Brooklyn uses the same yeast for all their beers, lager or not, I can always tell when I drink one. I do appreciate them doing a beer in this style though. Solid though.

Keg at Kosmonaut, Manchester. Near black with golden-tinged head. Sort of a cocoa malty, cherry fruit and notably hoppy aroma. Quite complex. Taste for me is a step down from that level of complexity and a bit too fizzy, but with some nice sticky molasses. Well worth a try.
Decent beer. No aroma detected. Nice chocolate color with good lacing. Lighter weight but smooth. Slight woody flavor with a dark malt sweetness. Low hops presence.

Tap at the Lamb, Chiswick. Black tinged with red, and with a fine tan crema. Light aromas of coffee, milk chocolate and a little toasty caramel, then a rich malty coffee and cocoa body. Peppery and herbal hoppy bitterness in the finish. Pine and dry-bitter chocolate emerging as the chill lifts. Lovely.

Draft. Poured clear dark brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Medium toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium dark sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of average duration. This beer met my expectations.

Bottle at home. Coffee, pumpernickel, cracked rye, pine. Smooth palate, well attenuated, very little residual sugar. Bitter cocoa powder as it warms. Complex finish with a big round roasty malty feel. Drinks like a full bodied porter.
Nice dark color. Caramel scent. Nice full flavor for a lager. Very good and would have again. Tap

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Clear dark brew with dense tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma blends toasted malts, sweet malts, grassy hops and some sweet dark fruits and a little spice. Taste is sweet and roasted malts up front with a little earth, grass and spice emerging towards the finish. Ends dry with a flourish of pepper. Nicely complex.

Bottle from The Beerhive. Dark brown body with a thick beige head. Good lacing. Aroma of earth, Coco Pops and wood. Flavour of lightly roasted malt, dirt, coffee and a subtle, hoppy finish. Thin body with a light texture. Average carbonation. Well balanced and easy drinking.

Bottle. This is a solid beer but not like any other dunkel I have. It lacks the malt quality of central European examples. Very heavily hopped, too much for the style. Some flavor of ash, and hop bitterness that overpowers what should have been rich malt flavor. It is good, but not a great example of a dunkel.

Dark brown color. Big , tan head. Aroma of caramel , toasted malt , herbal hops . Balanced taste with moderate malty sweetness and decent, hoppy bitterness at the end. Notes of roasted caramel in aftertaste. I missed good dunkel beers, but this is a good one .

Poured from bottle. 
Aroma of caramel and molasses. 
Appearance is like a porter. Could use more head . 
Tasting lots of hops for a lager . Also roasted malt, caramel, licorice and burnt coffee.
Palate is a little rough at first but mellows as it warms. Has lager and porter traits.
Overall, a unique and interesting beer.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle poured with big tan head black liquid. Faint roasty burnt nose. Roasty malt profile, lighter palate, finished burnt that lingers faintly. Hops hidden through dark malt. Pleasant.

Pours dark amber with an off white head. Nose is a gentle roast with just a touch of sweetness. Flavor is of a brown malt with hints of smoke in the background. Sharply carbonated. Quick finish. Decent stuff.

Pours clear dark brown with low light tan head. Aroma of light chocolate, roasted malt, rye bread. Taste is sweet, lightly roasty with mellow bitter finish. Body is light and smooth with average carbonation.
Malt heavy aroma, light cocoa, maybe some berries too. Taste is malts, light cocoa, some berries, and then a nice sharp hop bite in the finish.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, best before 3/2016. Pours clear very dark brown color with a 1 finger dense and rocky tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Awesome appearance. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, herbal, grass, pepper, light smoke/char, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of roast/bready malt and earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, herbal, grass, pepper, light smoke/char, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Moderate herbal/spicy and roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, herbal, grass, pepper, light smoke/char, and herbal/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Outstanding complexity, robustness, and balance of roast/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great roast/hop bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Moderate dryness from roast and hop bitterness as well. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, crisp, moderately creamy/bready, and sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is an outstanding schwarzbier style. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of roast/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

On tap at DArcys in Bradley Beach. Full body, slick feel, average carbonation, bitter, but a nice change for a lager, very advanced for what the label classifies it. Medium wet head, drinks with the bite of a pilsner, the refreshment of a lager, but the dryness and fullness of a stout. Taste is coffee, pumpernickel bread, spices, and hops with a dry finish. Not exactly something Id polish off an entire six of, but a nice choice during winter for those craving a lager. So far never been displeased with this brewery.

Bottle. Nose on melanoidin overload, toasted bread crusts and pump, touch spice, roast, sweet, surprising coffee. Pours pitch black with a large and jiggly tan head. Medium-full body sharply and strongly bitter with heavy roast and coffee overtones, lingering impression is of bitter, astringent black malt. Touch of spruce and general wood, light but very noble in the hop department, more dark bread with a light vein of caramel. Relatively dry when its all said and done, minimal alcohol and very crisp.  Its missing a deep malty center but is definitely what I call "hard bop" in its uncompromised, somewhat acrid roast and long aftertaste. Pleasant in all aspects -- I havent like a beer from Brooklyn this much in years! [2016.01.13: 3.8]

Pours dark brown-black with a one finger tan head with nice lacing. Aroma is of roasted bready malts, cold brew coffee, dark chocolate, citrus, grassy hops, caramel sweet malts, and some toffee. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and a semi bitter, semi dry, toasty, long finish. Overall, a very nice winter lager that is actually quite session able unlike a lot of winter beers.

appearance: very dark brown, one finger of creamy tan head, good lacing. aroma: coffee and toasted nuts, with some grassy and citrusy hops.  taste: dark chocolate, cold-pressed coffee, almond skins, grassy/citrusy hops.  finish: lingering black toast, light minerality. Notes: Feels more like a schwarzbier. Whatever it is, its darn good. Nice palate. Creamy, but the hops are lively enough to keep things really drinkable. Bottle from The Beer & Wine Cellar, the best new bottle shop in Rockville.
Black pour from draft at Hopsmith. White head. Malty and cocoa flavor. Coffee maybe, some hops. Not bad at all
Keg in Bears and Bungalows, Sheffield. Pours ruby with a foamy cream head. Not a lot of aroma. The taste is toasty and fruity with light spice, nut, liquorice and an ashy bitter finish. Pretty tasty.

Bottle pour into shaker pint glass. Aroma is rich roasted bready malt with some caramel and chocolate. Appearance is similar to a cola--very dark brown (though a little mahogany-tinged) with tons of sparkle. Tiny beige head with fair persistence and minimal lacing. Taste is similar to aroma--moderate roasted malty sweetness with chocolate and a bit of bitter roasted coffee at the finish. Palate is medium-to-full bodied with a velvety, sultry but surprisingly light texture, lively carbonation and crisp, dry finish. Overall, this packs a lot of aroma and flavor into a surprisingly light palate and ABV.

Roasty with a hint of citrus, nutty and dry, hints of char, herbal notes and cocoa; subtle, yet deeply complex; deep brown color with a frothy beige head; medium-bodied and goes down quite smooth. This was the best and my favorite new beer of the season (New Belgium Accumulation was second) and I keep buying 6-packs and having it on tap whenever I see it! I really hope Brooklyn decides to make this a mainstay offering as it is about as good and interesting as a black lager can get. Keep up the great work!

Dark brown pour, red hues, finger of pancake tan head. Nose is dark malt with a hint of coffee. Middle is black patent malt, medium bitter coco, some lupine character. Finish is bittersweet, hints of pine bitterness, but ultimately smooth.

From a 12 Oz into a pint glass. Pours slightly sear brown with a bunch of frothy white head and some lacing. Light but good Mouthfeel. Taste is totally lacking. Some mild chalk but thats it. Wtf. And I thought this was a Schwartzbier? Eh avoid.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. Dark and tasty, perfect for a cold night to warm you up a bit. Not too heavy on the hops which is always good.
deep,dark brown to blackcolor; nice, chocolaty, roasted malt aroma; medium bodied; roasted malt flavor with lots of chocolate notes; well balanced; very smooth

Bottle. Light roast malt nose, with light chocolate, some coffee, quite earthy. Dark translucent brown, quickly dissipating tan head. Roast, tangy dark fruit, some licorice -- all sort of lightly burnt -- with a gentle bitter finish. Thin-medium body. Frisky fruit. Pretty good.
A nice winter warmer, which tastes nothing like a lager. Slightly sweet, plum and cherry fruit. Dark roast. Light finish. Great companion to bbq.
355ml bottle from work. A really nice dark lager. Pretty choppy. Crisp and drinkable.

Bottle to shaker glass, pours black, deep red hue when held to light. Light khaki 2 finger silky head. Some lacing and decent retention. Aroma of dark roasted barley malt. Taste is sweet, nicely balanced bitterness. Medium-light bodied, moderate carbonation, silky mouth feel. Finishes dry. Tasting notes of coffee, dark chocolate, tree nuts, roasted barley and floral hop notes. Decent and drinkable.

Deep heavy dark brown with a thin off beige head. Earthy roasted biscuity nose with something almost licorice-y. Smooth medium body with licorice and earthy toast on the flavor. Weird licorice-y aftertaste.
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. Inky black with a thin tan head. It has a sweet citrus and chocolate flavour with a malty body followed by a nutty, red fruit and pine finish. Excellent!

Draft at Brass Rail. Dark brown, creamy brown head, fairly heavy lacing. Caramel malt sons with some light coffee and earthy notes. Lightly sweet, lightly roasted, and a bit of bitterness on the close. Clean and very drinkable. Smooth finish. Solid beer.
12 ounce bottle. Clear brown color with a beige head of foam. Good retention. Caramel and toffee notes, some nutty character. Medium sweetness. Medium body and medium carbonation.
355ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours black with thick beige head. Aromas of malted coffee, chocolate. Taste is sweet coffee and more chocolate. Creamy texture, bitter middle, dry finish.

Bottle from Appellation Wines Comely Bank. 
Appearance - olive black with a crema head.
Nose - roast and subtle chocolate. 
Taste - creamy sweet malt and more subtle chocolate.
Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish.
Overall - enjoyed this.
bottle. Deep brown with one finger head. Roasty malt body. Coffee and chocolate with substantial roast nuttiness. Medium hops in the finish. Decent.

boozy aroma with malt,hoppy caramel and gravy. some mild watered down kind of sweetness and a butterscotch type of thing going on. light herbs in the background with pine. sudsy with an aroma that does not quit. interesting.

Insulated Dark Lager has a thin-to-medium, cream-colored head, a very dark (almost black) brown appearance, and splotchy, thin lacing left on the glass. The aroma is of dark malt, some black cherry, bread crust, and a bit of coffee. Taste is of sweet, roasted malt, bread crust, a slight char, and low bitterness. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Brooklyn Insulated Dark Lager finishes crisp and warming. RJT

Poured from the tap into a pint glass. The appearance is a dark brown with a large tan colored head. The aroma is a full on hop experience. the taste is hoppy with some pepper and a good blend of malt that has a dry effect on the palate. A fairly unique flavored beer from Brooklyn.

Sampled on draft at Champs in Altoona this beer poured a black color with orange highlights and a large foamy tan head that faded and left minimal lacing. The aroma was toasty malts, a bit of roasty malts, vanilla, cola and dark fruit. The flavor was malty and bitter with dark fruits, roastiness and molasses. Medium length finish. Medium body. Ok.
Very dark red, almost black, and a big beige head. Very faint aroma. mostly coffee and toast. Taste is coffee, some ashy notes, and hints of banana. Seems a bit watery, which actually works here.

Somewhere in Tartytown: pours a near black with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, mollasses, a hint of fruitiness, and sugar. Taste is roasty and moderately sweet. Small amount of hoppiness right at the finish. Almost a bit chewy. Nice aftertaste. Quite good.

Bottle at Winking Lizard. Dark mahogany color with a medium thick off-white head that diminishes steadily to a film. Malt, chocolate and hops in the nose. Light to medium body with flavors of chocolate malt, roasted coffee and mild hops. The finish is roasty with a malty aftertaste. Decent overall.
Pours very black with a white head. Taste is surprisingly light considering the colour. Has the hoppy flavour of a Pilsner, the malt is subtle. Went very well with a burger.

Bottle from Whole Foods. It pours dark brown with a small beige head. The nose is bitter-sweet, earthy roast, coffee, rivita, prune juice and molasses. The taste is bitter, earthy roast, light liquorice, coffee, cocoa, light charred woods, toasted nuts and peppery spice with a dry, roasted finish. Medium body and average carbonation. Well-rounded and rather drinkable.
Bottle. Clear, dark brown with a medium light-tan head. Aroma is dark roasted grains with with hints of coffee. Taste is dark toast, roasted grains with hints of coffee.
Bottled Poured a deep brown. Malts and a bit of sourdough. Not bad overall really......

Brooklyn Brewery Insulated Lager 5.6% 

Pouring black with ruby highlights and a thick pillowy beige head of foam this beer has a nice aroma of berries, citrus zest and cookie like malt character in the aroma.

The taste is roasty chocolate & nuts then big citrusy hops before ending on almonds and chocolate muffins. Really welcoming and comforting on a dreary winter day. Good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

BB date of March 2016.
This was poured into a pilsener glass.
The appearance was a dark brown color with a rocky off white to almond two finger head. Lacing was semi-sticky and coating the glass somewhat in a glaze of rings.
The smell takes in roasted nuts, (I almost want to say almonds) with a subtle dry roasted cocoa beans. Light cake-like aroma to level out the aroma.
The taste was balanced between the sweet and the dry roastiness. Nuts, almonds, caramel, toffee and cocoa round out to warm on into the aftertaste. Theres a slight sticky finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a sessionability that makes me want to sip. Im sipping a lager, why yes I am. Damn right and you know, I realize theres nothing wrong with that.
Overall, as a Munich Dunkel Lager, Id say it works. Makes for a nice winter beer that isnt too overbearing.
Mild wood aroma. Clear ruby brown, thin head. Rich wood, maple syrup, walnut. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Intense, complex, rustic.
Not a big fan. Some Porter like coffee and dark roast notes, but also dusty and a little lifeless. Little complexity and a watery body.

12 oz. bottle from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); shared with Boo. Aroma: Dry, chocolate-like malts with some light roast and espresso qualities; maybe a pinch of herbal hops. Appearance: Dark ruby brown pour with a foamy khaki head that settles into a sticky skin. Flavor: Dark chocolate and roasted malts are the mainstays here; espresso mingles with an herbal bitterness towards the finish, which is dry. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: A very well done American take on the Dunkel.
Pours a very dark brown color with no real head retention or lacing. Smells like coffee and is very reminiscent of a porter. It tastes the same, but drinks very lightly. Solid drink here.

Bottle from Glug Newcastle. Very nice stuff - flavours of roasts, Malts, and an intriguing heat. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep Brown pour with a white head. The aroma is very light with some bready notes. It has a full body with slightly chewy texture and average carbonation. The taste is roasted with a dry finish.
Bottle. Chocolate malt and straw aroma. Dark brown with large tan head. Sweet chocolate malt and mildly bitter herbal hay flavor. Body on the light side. Okay.

Location/Date:Bottle in November.
Appearance: Pours a dark opaque brown. 
Aroma: Aroma of light coffee
Taste: Light bitterness, light coffee, light caramel.
Palate:Light medium body.
Summary: I really enjoyed this beer. Well balanced, light coffee flavors, not heavy body.
Drank from a pint glass poured from a twelve ounce bottle, thank you Danny! Smells like a hop bomb. But deliciously complex and not over powering by the hops. Good beer!

Higher hopes for this dark lager. Initially I think it has a little too much personality, Another swig says the same, somewhat like a schwartz but a little more volatile. Seems more like 6 or 7%. Yes, almost astringent at times. Gets nearly annoying toward the end of the session; was wishing for a more mild well behaved laid back feel to this one.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very dark color with a thick long lasting tan head. aroma is of roasted coffee beans Taste is also of coffee, dark chocolate, and cola. just a touch of bitterness. nice finish.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2016 I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours a dark brown color with a nice tan head and lacing. The aroma is roasty, coffee, and chocolate. The taste is roasted coffee, some chocolate, and hops. It?s balanced pretty nicely with above average carbonation. This was pretty solid.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Clear dark brown, medium sized foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of roasted malts, nuts, chocolate. The taste is nuts, roast, chocolate. Medium bodied, crisp dry. Solid.

Pours a dark mahogany with a thick, long-lasting off-white foam head and some lacing. Aroma is caramel, burnt, toasty malts, roast, nut, and some earthy, spicy hops. Flavor is caramel, toast, and nut. Has a crisp, smooth body. Excellent.
Bottle. Cola colored with off white head. Dark roasted malt, coffee and a little cocoa. Medium crisp body. Pretty tasty.

12 oz. Clear mahogany body has a lasting disc of creamy foam. Nose is mild espresso with bits of dark chocolate toffee and citrus. Tastes of the same mix with a dry finish of toasted walnut, ash and unsweetened cocoa powder. Near-medium body has medium-high, but mostly smooth carbonation and a nice balance.

Draft. Medium tan head atop crystal clear dark brown body, nice lacing. Aroma is moderately sweet, roast, caramel, light chocolate, earthy, lager yeast. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some roast, orange, light earthy. Light-medium body.
Draft. Clear brown color, tan head. Aroma of toasted caramel. Taste has burnt caramel on a lager background. OK.

Bottle:
Nearly black, rubied, with a chunky tan head.
Cola, coffee, chocolate scent.
Slightly earthy coffee malt, roast, dark grain flavour.
Nicely malty...slightly bitter.
Pretty good.....simple.
Has a nice aroma and good taste. Pours really dark. Really good for a cold winters day.

Bottle. Moderate roasted grain for the malt, light herbs and dough for the hops and yeast, with toffee and brown sugar in the background. Head is small, frothy, off-white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear dark brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and faintly bitter. Palate is medium, watery with a lively carbonation. Pretty tasty and lightly warming Dunkel.

bready, mild cocoa, sweet citrus, faint molasses, herbal/pine noble hop, roasty/grain husky astringency on the finish. Wish the mouthfeel was a tad more substantial but other than that a nice dark lager.

Bottle. Archer Road Beer Stop, Sheffield. Clear, very dark, chestnut brown. Film, and a few bubbles of off white head. Roast coffee bean malts. Dried vine fruits. Taste has a dried fruit sweetness. Turns light dry. Smooth palate. Finishes fruity dry, with a hint of roast coffee bitterness. Not my preferred style, but found this pretty drinkable.

12oz bottle poured into a sam adams glass. Dark brown/black pour with an off white head and lots of legs. Delicious sweet notes of burnt roasted malts, coffee, cola and dark chocolate. Full body. Great brew.
Pours dark brown, almost black with a thick tan head. Aroma is a little lacking, some cola, some coffee. Very smooth, woody notes with some coffee too. A pretty nice dunkel.

Deep, opaque bowling-ball matte black, pretty nice head. 

Aroma is a chalky, tobacco-y, charcoaly kinda deal. Some nice cola notes. Touch of cinnamon. The more I stick my beak into it, the more I like it.

The taste is some dark berries. There is a charcoal flavor, and a touch of leather. Just a touch of sugary black licorice. 

Feels very chalky and dry. This is a very nice dark lager. Reminds me of a smoky Schwartzbier.

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty weak earthy hoppy caramel aroma. Fruity malty grainy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel bitter hoppy finish.

Bottle shared that pours a medium brown with long lasting tan head and decent lacing, in the nose you get roasted malts pils malt slight bitterness and hops. The flavor produced more of the same a good lager base with the pils malt but the extra layer of the roasted malts is actually quite good and does not over power other flavors. Strange style to begin with but still quite tasty.
Fat på brooklyn brewery nyc. Bärnstensfärgad. Rostad doft med en ganska frukthumlig avslutning. Maltig smak med viss rökighet och citrus
Fat på brooklyn brewery. Mörkt brun med beige skum. Bränd rökig doft med lite fruktighet. Lättdrucken med mycket smak av hårt rostad malt.
